page.title: 02LANDSCAPE.
page.content: The landscape around Berkhamsted is a reflection of both natural and manmade features.The Berkhamted Valley runs from N.W.to S.E. cuttng through the Chiltern Hills, an area of chalk and clay. The valley is between 105m and 180m above sea level.It is at the southernmost limit of glaciation and the smooth rounded form of the valley is evidence of the valley previously beng a glacial meltwater channel. This has resulted in alluvial soils being deposited in the valley with chalk, clay and flint on the valley sides. 50% of the block is covered by urban development, being comprised of industry, commerce and housing. The S.W.side of the valley is the more developed. The higher land, to the N.E. and the S.W.is fine undulating agricultural land with some woodland.
